and vague enough where it seems like he, and we don't know his heart, but it seems like he's
trying to not say, Hey, we still believe this. This is what we've chosen to do. It's just vague
enough. And so it leaves space for people to assume, Oh, you've changed your opinions on things.
You're not standing for whatever anymore, you know, which, which I think, I think two things,
like you're saying, they are part of discovery and HBO max, which are in no way Christian networks
and not saying Christians shouldn't interact with those platforms or engage with them or
partner with them. But you have to know that at some point your values are going to come into
conflict. Right. If you're under contract with or working closely with people of the,
such a different worldview. And also if their views have changed, that also happens when you're
in close communication and, and community with people who, you know, have a different worldview
and you're influenced by the people you're around. So who, who knows which is which, but yes. Yeah.
I think like you're saying the vagueness and the lack of affirming what they still believe
left a lot of room for people to be upset. I think it doesn't help that in the secular world,
um, like that people have come forward and crowed about it in the secular world. Like they think
they just gotten, they just won a battle for the hearts of some Christian icons. There are very
few Christian icons out there, leaders in the community of, you know, of this type of community
of, of media presenters and that kind of stuff. There just aren't a lot of Christians. And this
was a couple who though maintaining very strong Christian values still somehow managed to pry
success out of the world with this. And the response from like the LGBTQ world has been,
I just saw a quote that just said referred to the experience as a great, amazing opportunity to
normalize same sex couples and same sex families. So that's how they see it. That couple is the one
that said that the couple that's being featured. Yeah. And so they saw this as, Hey, we're
influencing the Christian culture. We're going to help the Christian culture understand this is okay.
They're going to see this and go, this is healthy and good and normal. So they see it as proselytizing.
And so, but that, that to me is like, did you get, do like, that's all the questions. Did you guys
get duped into doing this? Did you sign a bad contract for this? Did you, or did you know this
going in and you chose to do it anyway? And what was your motivation? Is it that you've changed?
Like you said, and there's just so many questions left open. And when you don't interpret yourself
for people, they will interpret you for themselves. And they've left some to this open
I'm glad they go to scripture with their responses. That implies
at least that they see scripture as authoritative. But again, it's, it's a,
it's just a tough, it's a tough sell. That's a, let me read another quote from him. This is why you get
confusion. It's not about what color you're this is chip again. It's not about what color your skin
is, how much money you have in the bank or political affiliation, sexual orientation,
gender nationality, or faith. That's all fascinating, but it cannot add or take away
from the reality that we're already pulling for you. We are not about to get in the nasty
business of throwing stones at each other. Don't ask us to, cause we don't play that way.
And again, it at its face value under the right context, there might be, that might be a very
appropriate thing to say, but the question is, does his audience, what does, how does his audience
interpret something that's, that's as unclear as that? Could we as Christians, as we talked to,
and we went, we went deep into this question of the, is the Bible, what was the word we used?
Immoral by today's standards. And one of the topics was, I'm in regards to sex. And then we
unpack that for several, several episodes and tried to pull no punches one way or the other.
Let's look at what it really says and what this is about. And that was of all those different
topics, slavery, sexism, et cetera. That was the one that we came to. Essentially the answer is,
yes, by today's standards, if you judge the Bible by today's standards, the Bible is,
would be immoral in that it condemns same sex behavior as sin and immoral. And therefore,
because this culture affirms same sex behavior as moral and sometimes even highly virtuous,
like it's the apex version of love. All the, I mean, every, almost every episode of psychology
today, which I automatically get sent to my office just because I'm an advertiser on their
website, which there you go. There's maybe a connection to that, but is a, is always an
article about how to really learn to love well written by a gay or lesbian person, because
they're the ones who really understand it. And so in my mind, that's, that's an intriguing,
that's the world we live in. And so we just live in a, in a world that is divided there. And they're
trying to kind of take that third, it sounds to me like Chipp and Joanna are trying to take that
third stance that like, I have several friends who are part of a church down in Austin, that that's
their kind of their mantra is our church takes no stance on LGBTQ issues, biblical or otherwise.
And so each person gets to decide what they believe about it. And
but how do you get to pick and choose that? That's, that's tough, isn't it? Yeah.
They just decided to, cause that if we could that make, it's like, we, I mean, we've had those
conversations before. I would be all about that. Believe me. If we could, if it's like,
if I could affirm it, if I could reconcile that in the Bible, if I could believe what feels best
to me. Right. That's right. And so that is interesting. It's, it's tough and it does create
a controversy and it is difficult. And so my, my response, our response at this point has really
just kind of been to pray for them. And, and you know, I've gotten to meet them and, and one time
got to shake hands and talk about pocket tools with chip. And, and I have appreciated their
ministry. And in my opinion, this does not end any of that inherently. It just, it just becomes
a more complicated conversation with that. That is kind of heartbreaking that I get like had the
few years of silence began to wear on them that they couldn't break back into the, into the media
community. And this was the price. And that's, you know, you're tempted to wonder about that.
I do think we had a comment also on, so, so one, once again, remember we, whether it's Michael Tate
or Chip and Joanna Gaines or the couple at the Cold Blade concert, like we don't, we don't put
our faith in humans. All very different. Aren't they amazing how radically different they are.
They might inspire someone to deconstruct the fallenness of humans and that you just can't
trust people or even people, Christian leaders, it turns out are just as jacked up as other people or,
or that people may pay a price or not communicate it well or compromise. Or I just think one of the
things I immediately thought when people were, was spotting, I was like, right, because chip is
obviously being a home deconstruction and reconstruction guy is fully prepared for this
type of communication nightmare. Like he's, he's been well-trained at like, no, this is a guy who
tears down houses and builds them back. Like that's to put him in this situation and ask him
to handle this in an incredibly sophisticated way. He's super bright. Obviously he's very intelligent,
but that doesn't mean he's trained on having this type of communication. And I think clearly
he wasn't prepared for it or, or was over prepared. One of the two, he was either prepared to fight.
Or he needs to fire his publicist.
Yeah, there's PR. Listen, PR. Yeah, there's a lot of stuff there. But I will also say we published,
I don't know when this is going to go out, but we published recently
an older article or an older episode about human suffering and the difficulties and challenges of
that. And so, man, another thing that can, we talked about that this is one of the leading
causes of deconstruction is other people deconstructing or failing, letting us down. And it turns
out that our faith was in them. And we've always, one of our almost borderline mantras on this
podcast has been you do need to deconstruct your faith in humans and instead reconstruct some faith
in God himself. And also, can I add something to that? I think also, I mean, completely agree. I
think the second piece of this is like we've said a hundred times. It's also why it's so important
to know what you, why you believe what you believe, because at some point you will face pressure to
believe something different. And the narrative, like you're saying, the narrative of the world
is trying to redefine what love is, what acceptance is. And if you are not convinced
that God's way and ethic and way to life is best, then you will fall. I'm not saying this is what's
happened to them, but it is tempting to want to take the path that feels most loving. And if you
haven't done that really hard work of saying like, no, this is what God says and it is truly best and
loving, then at some point we're all going to face that pressure of like culturally, like you're
saying, this is a hard thing to engage with. And it starts to affect you in a deconstructed
aspect of like, man, is that what God says? Is he actually good to say that? Like how can that be
loving in all those questions? And so just another reason to do the hard work so that when we all
face that pressure to do the thing that feels most acceptable or most comfortable or whatever
our reason is specifically, that we'll know why we believe it.
Yeah, I think that's key. And I think that goes back to that, is that we have to be prepared to
know what our beliefs are and it can't be dependent on another human. We're just asking for trouble.
So that's been our push from day one. And then we're then, because there's plenty of questions
to ask about like why a loving God allows hundreds of people to die in floods in Texas,
including ones at camps where children sit and worship Him. Why would He? Like there's plenty
of hard questions about God and God Himself and the issues of dealing with God without complicating
like, well, but what does it mean when people fall? Well, what it means is people fall and they're
going to. And all of us are flawed at the very best. And if you knew us better, you would know
just how deeply flawed we can be. All of us have things that if it were revealed, we would be
covering our face and turning away from the camera. All of us have those things. And so
that's why we need a Savior to come in from the outside and save us, because it's not going to be
us that does it. So that's been a big part of our purpose in this all along has been. And it has
been intriguing how we've been doing this now what four or five years. And there are still always
examples of leaders who fall, Christian leaders who fall and who deconstruct and who walk away.
And like, and I feel like we may be, you know, these are examples that we will never run out of
because and I think that's exactly what Scripture would teach. So anyway, this has been great.
Hope it's been helpful to people to for just to even if they're just engaging with us as we
talk through it, if you've got questions or specific things like that. I had another idea
that we ought to talk about at some point. If you guys haven't caught up on the chosen, I haven't.
But I thought that might be have we done an episode on the chosen? I think that might be
a fun thing. I've had some people ask about chosen controversies and, and that kind of stuff that
might be a fun thing that people are building their faith or really challenging, challenging
their faith. And so I think that'd be a good one for us to talk about some point. Maybe we can see.
Cool. Alrighty. Alright.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
